abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, with substantial
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons specific
            to St. Kitts and Nevis suggest that projects like this one,
            can bring disaster management into the mainstream, not just
            through implementation of works and procurement of disaster
            supplies, but through consistent supervision, and
            consciousness raising. Lessons relevant to emergency
            operations as a whole suggest priority in this type of
            projects, should be given to prevention, immediate measures
            to reactivate economic activity, and careful assessment of
            longer-term reconstruction priorities and designs; that it
            would have been preferable to process the various
            loans/credits for the different OECS countries, as separate
            projects, part of a broader program, but not integrated into
            one horizontal APL; that careful attention should be given
            to the project unit manpower, particularly given local
            capacity constraints; that terms of reference for consulting
            engineers, should specify government budget constraints to
            avoid unaffordable infrastructure, while the Bank should
            also require performance guarantees of consultants, and
            apply penalties for late submissions, as needed.
